awd_titl_txt: CC* Network Infrastructure: Enabling Research with Mines' Underground Research Facility
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides funds to install extensive cyberinfrastructure and expand Wide-Area Network (WAN) speeds to the Colorado School of Mines' Edgar Underground Educational and Research Facility.  Such cyberinfrastructure upgrades further establish the Edgar Underground Educational and Research Facility as the premier facility for innovative research in underground environments.  Furthermore, this facility provides an environment for students, educators, researchers, and external partners to collaborate across a wide variety of scientific and engineering disciplines.  As a result of the project, researchers can better leverage campus, public, and private resources efficiently and expand research opportunities in areas such as underground communications and networking; sub-surface studies of microbial genetics and environmental DNA; remote monitoring of geologic features, seismic, electric or magnetic anomalies; and remote and autonomous control of terrestrial and aerial robots.

The Colorado School of Mines' Edgar Underground Educational and Research Facility is located 25 miles west of main campus in Idaho Springs, CO.  Due to the challenges of the surrounding terrain and remote location of the Edgar Facility, commodity ISP provides only one bonded pair of DSL lines, for a maximum download speed of 20Mbsec.  One goal of this project to establish a 10Gb network connection to the Edgar Facility using a combination of leased fiber from the FrontRange GigaPOP and 10Gb P2P wireless communication to connect the final half-mile that spans rugged terrain.  A second goal is to create robust cyberinfrastructure within the Edgar Facility, allowing connections to instrumentation and providing redundant network pathways within the mine.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The National Science Foundation (NSF) funded Edgar Experimental Mine Project aimed to revolutionize this historic mine into a cutting-edge research facility. This ambitious project focused on establishing a robust communication and IT infrastructure to unlock the mine's full research potential.

The project set several key goals. Firstly, achieving high-speed connectivity was paramount. This involved establishing Layer-2 connectivity from the main Mines campus via the Front Range GigaPop (FRGP), replacing the unreliable and slow DSL connection previously used. Secondly, the project aimed to provide robust data transfer within the mine itself. This was achieved by installing a 10Gb WAN connection to the surface buildings using directional wireless access points. Additionally, an armored fiber optic backbone with a wireless network was deployed throughout the mine workings, ensuring flexible and reliable data transfer across the entire underground facility.

Beyond just connectivity, the project aimed to bridge the service gap between the Edgar Mine and the main campus. Faculty and students working within the mine now enjoy comparable IT services and support as their counterparts on campus. This includes access to the campus information security infrastructure, extending the crucial layer of protection to the Edgar Mine network.

Enabling seamless data transfer was another significant goal. The project facilitated high-speed data transfer between the Edgar Mine and both the main campus and external entities. This allows researchers to efficiently share large datasets and collaborate seamlessly with colleagues across locations.

The project's impact extends far beyond simply enabling communication. The advancements made have significantly enhanced the Edgar Mine's research capabilities. A noteworthy innovation is the development of an RFID tracking system. This system leverages WiFi and sensor technology to achieve highly accurate (5-10 feet) underground location tracking. This breakthrough technology has the potential to revolutionize mine safety, improve operational efficiency, and enhance data collection within mining operations.

The project's impact transcends the realm of research and development. It has fostered advancements in various disciplines by facilitating data collection, analysis, and collaboration within the unique underground environment. Educational experiences have also been transformed. Students now benefit from:

  • Real-time data analysis and software utilization during underground courses.
  • Access to online or blended courses, expanding educational opportunities.
  • Remote lectures and participation from guest speakers, enriching the learning experience.

The project also highlighted the critical role of reliable communication in underground spaces. Improved safety is a key benefit, achieved through faster emergency response times and enhanced coordination among personnel. Additionally, real-time data transmission enables better decision-making and increased operational efficiency. Furthermore, the project lays the groundwork for the development of autonomous technologies in underground environments, with potential applications for tasks like automated deliveries or inspections. The technology developed at the Edgar Mine could also benefit critical infrastructure in cities, such as subway systems and sewage networks, by enabling improved monitoring and maintenance.

The Edgar Mine project serves as a valuable testing ground for novel communication technologies. By fostering collaboration across disciplines and knowledge sharing, the project holds promise for significant advancements in communication solutions for various fields requiring reliable underground connectivity.

In conclusion, the Edgar Experimental Mine Project has successfully transformed the mine into a premier underground research facility. The established high-speed communication infrastructure offers significant benefits for research, education, and safety in underground environments. The project's advancements also hold promise for broader societal impacts by contributing to the development and maintenance of critical infrastructure and paving the way for innovative technologies.
